results.title: The Life in your hands
results.creator_credit: Anti Cancer Council and R. Barrington-Scott
results.brief_description: Emphasises precautions women should take against breast cancer and cancer of the cervix. By regularly checking for breast lumps and having smear tests, women can detect these cancers at an early stage. Narrated by Fred Parslow.

results.title: Autism: who cares
results.brief_description: Four centres for autistic children in Victoria show how they deal with this problem. Details how they are able to teach the children to eventually integrate into the community. Photographer: Leigh Tilson; Music: Franciscus Henri, Philip Gardner, Audrey Klein.

results.title: Another day
results.creator_credit: Anti Cancer Council, Jennie Blackwood and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: Views of a number of people who have suffered from cancer leading normal happy lives. Stresses the importance of seeking medical advice and aid at the first suspicion that one has contracted the disease.

results.title: Uncle Bill
results.brief_description: Set against the industrial backdrop of a post-World War II Australian steel manufacturing town, multimedia artist Debra Petrovitch’s semi-autobiographical work Uncle Bill is a dark and disturbing narrative that explores a young girl’s memories of growing up in a harsh and at times violent environment. A cross-platform interactive CD-ROM, Uncle Bill takes the viewer on a journey that investigates memory, catharsis and child abuse through the interface of interactive, non-linear technology.Raw and unrelenting, Uncle Bill is an unsettling work that investigates the ways in which interactive technology can be used to explore complex, emotional and highly charged subject material.

A cross-platform interactive CD-ROM, Uncle Bill takes the viewer on a journey that investigates memory, catharsis and child abuse through the interface of interactive, non-linear technology.Raw and unrelenting, Uncle Bill is an unsettling work that investigates the ways in which interactive technology can be used to explore complex, emotional and highly charged subject material.

results.title: The Cute machine
results.brief_description:
‘The Cute machine’ is an exploration into the morphology of cute characterisation and iconography and its relationship to the biological world, seeking to analyse this ‘Cute ideal’ by correlating it with the Zoological process known as Neoteny

The CD contains two sections that had already been exhibited as installations (Sorry! and Activity Station) but were then adapted to a screen version. The remaining sections elaborate on the themes of cute iconography and its analysis.

The Cute Machine proposes an environment where cute iconography and user friendliness have rampantly accelerated, and reduced computer interface design to the look and sophistication of an infant toy, while also taking the premise, Cute = young to the extreme, where the ‘Cutest’, becomes an abstracted mutation of the original sentiment.

results.title: Bobe's legend
results.brief_description: Bobe’s Legend shows the artist joined in a symbiotic relationship with a young chick which, over a time-lapsed seqence, we see hatched and nurtured in the artist’s mouth until it eventually takes flight.

results.title: Spirited Away
results.brief_description: A young girl, Chihiro, becomes trapped in a strange new world of spirits. When her parents undergo a mysterious transformation, she must call upon the courage she never knew she had to free her family.
results.description:
During her family’s move to the suburbs, a sullen 10-year-old girl wanders into a world ruled by magical creatures. Separated from her parents, who have now been transformed into pigs, Chihiro embarks on a fantastical adventure in which she encounters talking toads, walruses, penguins and a sludge monster, among other bizarre deities and demons, on her quest to find her way home.

Spirited Away perfectly blends the unknown rules of the supernatural world with the young heroine’s unblinking acceptance of her new and strange environment.
description_for_label:

results.title: Mickey Mouse Model Sheet
results.credit_line:
Disney Studio Artist

Clean-up model sheet

Photostat on paper
results.description:
Mickey Mouse was created by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks, one of the leading animators of the time. Mickey Mouse first appeared to the public in Steamboat Willie, which was released in 1928. In an era when movies were moving from silent movies to “talkies”, which had synchronised sound, this film was the world’s first-ever “talkie” animation. The first films produced featuring Mickey Mouse were silent movies, including Plane Crazy (1928) and The Gallopin’ Gaucho (1928), which were completed prior to Steamboat Willie, but were released afterwards, when sound was finally added to them. Walt Disney supplied the voice of Mickey Mouse himself and would go on to voice Mickey for another 20 years.

This model sheet of Mickey Mouse represents the way that early animators had to learn how to make drawings move when they were animated. While this one only shows Mickey Mouse, they are created for all characters so that artists can convey all the principles of movement, including the effects of weight and heaviness, as well as what they’ll look like stretching or bouncing. It’s the art behind the animation and required studying physics and anatomy to create realistic, though fantastical, characters.
description_for_label:

The first films produced featuring Mickey Mouse were silent movies, including Plane Crazy (1928) and The Gallopin’ Gaucho (1928), which were completed prior to Steamboat Willie, but were released afterwards, when sound was finally added to them. Walt Disney supplied the voice of Mickey Mouse himself and would go on to voice Mickey for another 20 years.

While this one only shows Mickey Mouse, they are created for all characters so that artists can convey all the principles of movement, including the effects of weight and heaviness, as well as what they’ll look like stretching or bouncing. images.alt_text: A grid of 32 pictures of the iconic Mickey Mouse, with one giant Mickey in the middle, who is black skinned with big ears, a white belly and shorts on, who wears gloves. Each mickey image is posing differently.

results.title: Bambi
results.creator_credit: David D. Hand, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Animation Studios
results.credit_line:
Disney Studio Artist

Story sketch

Coloured pencil and graphite on paper
results.material_description: Coloured pencil and graphite on paper
results.brief_description: Acknowledged by generations of moviegoers as one of the greatest Disney animated classics ever produced, this extraordinary movie miracle is most fondly remembered as Walt Disney’s favourite picture. The simple, heartwarming story of the newborn ‘prince of the forest’ reflects the universal joy in us all as we discover the wonders of life and the beauty of nature. Each new revelation, along with bashful Flower and fun-loving Thumper, elevate this beloved classic to the status of timeless masterpiece. Nominated for five Academy Awards.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David D. Hand, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Animation Studios
results.description:
Walt Disney Animation Studio’s Bambi (1943) is one of the most visually striking and emotionally resonant and endearing animated features that the studio has ever produced. From the realistic animal animation and vivid, impressionistic backgrounds to the coming-of-age story at its centre, Bambi changed the way the studio approached animation and established one of its signature looks.

Walt Disney famously brought two fawns (baby deer) into the studio to help his animators create realistic illustrations. To get the attitudes and movements of animals in the wild right, he filmed hours of footage for the animators, and even had them study animal anatomy. But the cheerful faces of Bambi, Thumper and Flower were designed by an animator studying the expressions of human babies. When he translated those looks onto the drawings of animals, the adorable and expressive animal faces that have been the hallmark of the Studio’s subsequent films was born. The early concept sketch featured above is one of the earliest examples of this type of animation, and shows Bambi meeting his future friend Flower.

Friendship and love are at the heart of Bambi, which follows the princely deer from birth to adolescence and adulthood, with the trials and hardships of life also never overlooked. Instead, the film teaches audiences how to overcome life’s bitter winters, knowing that spring is always on its way. Apart from containing an ageless wisdom, Bambi is also one of the world’s first environmental films, which considers the destructive intrusion of man on nature, but its overarching message of peace, acceptance and harmony shows audiences there’s nothing love can’t conquer.

images.alt_text: A pencil sketch of the beloved Disney character Bambi, a small, bright-eyed deer who is leaning down to touch noses with a skunk emerging from a field of flowers. The image is taped to a sheet of paper by yellowing masking tape at the corners.
